first_reading.title: First Letter to the Corinthians
first_reading.text:
[[1_Co 7,25]]Brothers and sisters: In regard to virgins, I have no commandment from the Lord, but I give my opinion as one who by the Lord's mercy is trustworthy.
[[1_Co 7,26]]So this is what I think best because of the present distress: that it is a good thing for a person to remain as he is.
[[1_Co 7,27]]Are you bound to a wife? Do not seek a separation. Are you free of a wife? Then do not look for a wife.
[[1_Co 7,28]]If you marry, however, you do not sin, nor does an unmarried woman sin if she marries; but such people will experience affliction in their earthly life, and I would like to spare you that.
[[1_Co 7,29]]I tell you, brothers, the time is running out. From now on, let those having wives act as not having them,
[[1_Co 7,30]]those weeping as not weeping, those rejoicing as not rejoicing, those buying as not owning,
[[1_Co 7,31]]those using the world as not using it fully. For the world in its present form is passing away.

psalm.title: Psalms

gospel.title: Holy Gospel of Jesus Christ according to Saint Luke
gospel.text:
[[Lc 6,20]]Raising his eyes toward his disciples Jesus said: “Blessed are you who are poor, for the kingdom of God is yours.
[[Lc 6,21]]Blessed are you who are now hungry, for you will be satisfied. Blessed are you who are now weeping, for you will laugh.
[[Lc 6,22]]Blessed are you when people hate you, and when they exclude and insult you, and denounce your name as evil on account of the Son of Man.
[[Lc 6,23]]Rejoice and leap for joy on that day! Behold, your reward will be great in heaven. For their ancestors treated the prophets in the same way.
[[Lc 6,24]]But woe to you who are rich, for you have received your consolation.
[[Lc 6,25]]But woe to you who are filled now, for you will be hungry. Woe to you who laugh now, for you will grieve and weep.
[[Lc 6,26]]Woe to you when all speak well of you, for their ancestors treated the false prophets in this way.”
